dc:description:
*PQBP1* was first reported in relation to X-linked Renpenning syndrome in 2003 (Kalscheuer et al., PMID: ​14634649). Six frameshift variants that have been reported in nine probands in four publications (PMIDs: 14634649, 15024694, 15782410, 16493439) are included in this curation. Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 28 additional male family members, as well as in unaffected female carriers. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points) has been reached. The mechanism of pathogenicity is loss of function. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by a conditional knockout mouse model with significantly reduced brain weight (PMID: 25070536) and functional studies demonstrating the pathogenicity of loss-of-function variants (PMIDs: 23512658, 24781215, 28073926).

In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *PQBP1*​ and X-linked Renpenning syndrome. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Intellectual Disability and Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel on November 7, 2018 (SOP Version 6).

The relationship between PQBP1 and X-linked Renpenning syndrome was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of 9/27/18. Variants in PQBP1 were first reported in humans with this disease as early as 2003 (Kalscheuer et al.​). At least 7 frameshift variants, and additional missense and nonsense variants, have been reported in at least 9 male probands in 4 publications (PMIDs: 14634649, 15782410, 15024694, 16493439, 16740914, 20950397, 26411299, 25167861). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 28 additional male family members, as well as unaffected female carriers. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for "predicted or proven null variants" for genetic evidence (10 pts) has been reached. This gene-disease association is supported by a conditional knockout mouse model with significantly reduced brain weight (PMID: 25070536) as well as functional studies demonstrating the pathogenicity of loss-of-function variants (PMIDs: 23512658, 24781215, 28073926). In summary, PQBP1​ is definitively associated with X-linked Renpenning syndrome. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Autism and Intellectual Disability Working Group on 11/7/2018.

evidence.dc:description: tested binding of the YxxPxxVL motif of PQBP1 to U5-15kD, which is a spliceosomal uridine-rich small nuclear ribonucleoprotein particle (U snRNPs). Demonstrate that the frameshift variants cause loss of the YxxPxxVL motif that is essential for hydrophobic binding between PQBP1 and U5-15kD
evidence.rdfs:label: Mizuguchi Function

evidence.dc:description: the c.461_462delAG variant was confirmed in this study as being almost undetectable in patient cells; this study is consistent with the findings in patient lymphoblastic cell lines
evidence.rdfs:label: Zhang Non-Patient Cells

evidence.dc:description: Increased because this study includes a rescue model and demonstrates the pathogenicity of two variants reported in humans.

knock-down of PQBP1 in embryonic neurons led to substantially diminished dendrite branching and dendrite length. They showed this was not due to an increase in cell apoptosis. Supression of dendrite growth was rescued by human wild type PQBP1 but not disease mutants p.Y65C or deletion of AG
evidence.rdfs:label: Wang Non-Patient Cells

evidence.dc:description: Not scored because the mouse phenotypes are not very consistent with human phenotype

overexpressed PQBP1 in mice using CMV enhancer and chicken beta-actin promoter. PQBP1-mRNA, and not PQBP1 protein, is increased in these transgenic mice. F0 mouse showed late-onset motor neuron disease phenotype including loss of spinal lumbar motor neurons. Only one F1 mouse was found to have similar phenotype to the F0 mouse, the rest died bfore reaching age of onset of F0 mouse. No brain atrophy or malformation was seen in any mouse generation
evidence.rdfs:label: Okuda Animal Model

evidence.dc:description: downgraded because this is a conditional KO and there was no behavioral phenotyping.

conditional knockout mouse of PQBP1 in neural stem cells using nestin-Cre. Brain weight was decreased about 70% compared to background or floxed mice. No obvious differences in cerebral contrex layer structure or thickness of cortical layers. No change in cell death of ventricular zone (evaluated by Tunnel staining). No microcephaly was observed in synapsin-1-Cre derived PQBP1-cKO mice, suggesting that mutations in neural crest stem cells, and not neurons, cause microcephaly.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ito Animal Model

evidence.dc:description: CR SSCP analysis of PQBP1 - variant occurs in WW domain, potentially causes LOF by destabilizing residual fold and priming protein for disulfide bridge (Pucheta-Martinez 2016 27456546)
Predicted complete loss of C-terminal protein. Variant is absent from gnomAD. Variant is also seen to segregate in a family that was identified by Abdel-Salam et al. 2018 (30244542).
present in 118/19114 (0.6%) South Asian alleles

p.Arg155X variant is absent from gnomAD. Paper says the variant co-segregates, however no family data is provided.

evidence.dc:description: Variant is absent from gnomAD.
Variant is present in 1/16984 African alleles in gnomAD. Study shows that there is almost undetectable expression levels of PQBP1.
Variant seen in Germanaud 2011 proband, so scored again but downgraded.

Variant is absent from gnomAD. Proposed gain-of-function. "...binds non-phosphorylated fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP) and promotes ubiquitin-mediated degradation." (Zhang 2017 28073926). Kalsheuer tested patient lymphoblastic cell lines and found markedly reduced PQBP1 transcripts = predicted NMD
Variant is absent from gnomAD.
Downgraded because this paper only tested exon 4 of PQBP1 in MR males.

Downgraded because same variant is seen in multiple other families and this study only sequenced the PQBP1 gene, with no mention of linkage analysis.

Variant is absent from gnomAD. Proposed gain-of-function mechanism.  "...binds non-phosphorylated fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP) and promotes ubiquitin-mediated degradation." (Zhang 2017 28073926). Kalscheuer tested patient lymphoblastic cell lines and found markedly reduced PQBP1 transcripts = predicted NMD.
